metadata.title: Medical student concerns relating to neurosurgery education during COVID-19

abstract.text: The Coronavirus Disease 2019 pandemic has created significant obstacles within medical education. For medical students interested in pursuing neurosurgery as a specialty, educational policies surrounding COVID-19 present unique challenges. This study utilizes a nationwide survey to identify concerns held by students interested in pursuing neurosurgery during the COVID-19 pandemic.

Camps were sent an online Qualtrics survey, requesting them to assess how the COVID-19 pandemic was affecting their neurosurgical education. The Pearson Chi-Square test and post-hoc pairwise Fisher's exact test were used for analysis of categorical variables and the two-tailed paired Student's t-test was utilized for continuous variables.
The survey was distributed to 852 medical students with 127 complete responses.

Concerns regarding conferences/networking opportunities (63%), clinical experience (59%), and board exam scores (42%) were most frequently cited. 76% of M3s reported at least one cancelled/postponed neurosurgery rotation. On average, students were more likely to take a year off from medical school after COVID-19 than before the start of the pandemic, measured from 0 to 100 (25.3 ± 36.0 vs 39.5 ± 37.5; p = 0.004). Virtual mentorship pairing was the highest rated educational intervention suggested by M1s and M2s, while M3s and M4s cited virtual surgical skills workshops most frequently.

Conclusions: This nationwide survey highlights the concerns of medical students in neurosurgery education during the COVID-19 pandemic. With these findings, neurosurgery organizations can consider targeted plans for students of each year to continue their development.
• We sent a survey to U.S. med students interested in neurosurgery during COVID-19.
• Frequently cited concerns were networking, clinical experience, and board exams.

body_text.text: The Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic has created significant obstacles for physicians and medical educators regarding the delivery of healthcare and medical education.
For medical students interested in pursuing neurosurgery as a specialty, educational policies surrounding COVID-19 present unique challenges.

Neurosurgery is widely regarded as one of the most competitive specialties, evidenced by one of the highest average USMLE Step 1 scores and median publication rates 1 . Thus, medical students need to be highly engaged and productive during their preclinical and clinical years to build strong residency applications. At most institutions, formal exposure to neurosurgery during medical school is weighted towards the senior years, and it is often the responsibility of the student to explore the field during earlier years 2, 3 . Due to this absence of clinical exposure, medical students' perceptions of the field, often shrouded in stereotypes, weigh heavily on the decision-making process and have been the subject of recent studies 4, 5 . However, as might be expected, student perceptions are not static and are significantly shaped by increased exposure to the field, particularly after rotating through neurosurgery electives 6 and gaining increased experience in the neurosurgical operating room (OR) 7 .

In a time during which students are prohibited from the OR and exposure to neurosurgery is further limited, it is essential to recognize these limitations and devise methods to facilitate student engagement. To the authors' knowledge, factors related to the COVID-19 pandemic that affect medical student education in neurosurgery have not been investigated in a large nationwide cohort of U.S. medical students. The following study utilizes a nation-wide survey to identify the concerns held by neurosurgery-minded medical students during the COVID-19 pandemic and to understand what educational interventions are most desired by these students to ensure their continued development.

The Medical Student Neurosurgery Training Camp has been held annually since its inaugural year in 2018. 5, 8, 9 A registry of 852 medical students from across the U.S. who have registered for the training camp of any year was maintained by the authors. This large sample of U.S. medical students with an interest in neurosurgery was leveraged to outline the factors in question regarding the impact of COVID-19 on neurosurgical education.

Medical students in the training camp registry were sent an online survey via email, requesting their assessment of the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic upon their neurosurgical education. Demographic information, including current medical institution, medical trainee program/year, race, ethnicity, and gender, was collected. Baseline interest in neurosurgery was established by asking participants to rank their interest in neurosurgery as a potential specialty choice from 0 (tangential interest) to 100 (firm commitment) on a sliding scale. Respondents with stated interest less than 50 were excluded from data analysis to ensure our study captured students most invested in neurosurgery education.

In the survey (Supplemental Figure 1) , respondents were asked to describe how COVID-19 has impacted their neurosurgical education within several domains, including their clinical experience, research productivity, and networking opportunities. Students also identified ways in which neurosurgical organizations might better respond to medical students' evolving educational needs.

The online survey was designed and distributed using survey quality and distribution software (Qualtrics, Provo, UT). Survey responses were maintained confidential as was noted in the opening message of the survey. The study was approved by the Weill Cornell Institutional Review Board protocol number 20-04021871.

Microsoft Excel (Microsoft Corporation, 2018) and R statistical software (Vienna, Austria 2020, version 4.0.0) were used for statistical analysis and data visualization using a database of survey responses exported from Qualtrics. The Pearson Chi-Square test and post-hoc pairwise Fisher's exact test were used for analysis of categorical variables and the two-tailed paired Student's t-test was utilized for continuous variables. A p-value ≤ 0.05 was considered statistically significant.

The survey was distributed to a total of 852 students with 133 complete responses (completion rate 16%). A total of 6 respondents were excluded from the analysis due to a stated interest in neurosurgery less than 50 out of 100. Thus, a total of 127 responses were analyzed.

The breakdown of respondents by class year was 39 M1, 25 M2, 34 M3, and 13 M4 students, with 16 students in a different year of training (PhD year, research year, etc.). Respondents were seeking MD, MD/PhD, and DO degrees. Student demographics including gender, race, and Guadix 6 ethnicity were collected and broken down by med school year ( Table 1) . None of the student demographic factors varied significantly by year of medical training in our sample (NS).
However, comparing our aggregate student sample to historical data from the Accreditation Council of Graduate Medical Education (ACGME) 10

Students were asked which aspects of their neurosurgery residency application cycle acquisition rose significantly from M1 to M2 students (8% vs 56%, P < .001) and from M1 to M3 students (8% vs 56% P < .001). Other reported concerns included impact on preclinical grades, cancellation of summer research programs, and increasing the length of PhD programs. Rates of various clinical experiences being impacted by COVID-19 are summarized in Table 2 . Of note, the majority of M3 students reported cancellation of home (56%) and away (62%) neurosurgical sub-internships, with 76% (26/34) reporting at least one cancelled or postponed neurosurgical rotation. We identified cancellation or postponement of neurosurgery sub-internships at 25 different institutions. We also found that 54% (21/39) of M1 students reported cancellation of clinical shadowing days.
body_text.section: Medical Student Concerns Relating to COVID-19

body_text.text: From a research perspective, basic or translational research was stopped in 41% of cases, slowed in 35% of cases, was unchanged in 17% of cases, and was conducted at a faster rate in 8% of cases. Clinical research projects were stopped in 21% of cases, slowed in 36% of cases, experienced no change in 27% of cases, and increased in progress in 17% of cases (Figure 3) .
body_text.section: Medical Student Concerns Relating to COVID-19

body_text.text: Other means by which medical students are maintaining productivity are summarized in Table 3 .
body_text.section: Medical Student Concerns Relating to COVID-19

body_text.text: Students were asked to estimate a score from 0 to 100 regarding how likely they were to take a year off from medical school before the COVID-19 pandemic and how likely they are to take a year off at the time of their survey response (Figure 4 ). On average, students reported being more likely to take a year off from medical school after COVID-19 than before the start of the pandemic (25.3 ± 36.0 vs 39.5 ± 37.5; P = .004). While each class had a higher cumulative score for taking a year off after the COVID-19 pandemic, no individual class showed statistical significance on this measure (Table 4 ). M3 and M4 students cited virtual surgical skills workshops most frequently. Other suggestions from students included establishing firm consensus on changes to this year's application cycle and expanding access to virtual surgical simulation training.
body_text.section: Figure 3. The impact of institution-specific COVID-19 policies on the progress of ongoing lab-based and clinical research.

body_text.text: In this article, we attempt to quantify the effects of changes brought about by the COVID-19 pandemic on medical student's exposure and experience within neurosurgery. We found that there is near ubiquitous concern among survey responders, with students worried about the pre-clinical, clinical, and research portions of their neurosurgery application. This uncertainty faced by students was captured by our finding that students are significantly more likely to take a year off after the COVID-19 pandemic.
Among the COVID-related changes to clinical experiences, cancellation or postponement of neurosurgical sub-internships may have the biggest impact on neurosurgical applicants.

Without sub-internships, students will forgo opportunities to obtain letters of recommendation, gauge the cultural differences among neurosurgical training programs, and demonstrate their character and competence in clinical and OR settings. Consequently, in the upcoming residency application cycle, the focus may inevitably shift towards the more objective aspects of a residency application, such as board examination scores and clerkship grades.

From a research perspective, the biggest disruptions were to laboratory-based research projects. The majority of our respondents involved in basic or translational science research reported slowing or stopping of their project. This is not surprising, as many institutions have deemed laboratory research as "non-essential" and been forced to discontinue research. Clinical research was less affected than laboratory-based research, as might be expected. Interestingly, Guadix 13 nearly one-in-five respondents stated that clinical-research has accelerated, potentially due to increased time for students that have been removed from curricular responsibilities.

Cancellation of neurosurgical conferences was among the most frequently cited COVIDrelated changes, which is consistent with the cohort's high level of concern regarding the cancellation of conferences and loss of networking opportunities. This level of concern potentially stems from the weight that is placed on research productivity in the neurosurgical residency application. 11 Medical students were particularly concerned about loss of mentorship opportunities, highlighted not only by a high number of respondents citing this as a concern, but also by the fact that virtual mentorship pairing was the most frequently suggested educational intervention by early-year medical students (M1/M2).

Medical students are continuously looking for ways to remain productive and stay engaged during these times. Thus, it is imperative for departments to foster continued student engagement, mentorship, and exposure to neurosurgery. While virtual platforms have been used to facilitate continued productivity within neurosurgical departments, students should be invited to be involved as well. As an example, our institution has established a collaborative neurosurgery publication group 12 . Weekly virtual meetings are held to discuss ongoing projects, brainstorm new ideas, and foster mentorship with faculty.

Neurosurgical organizations and academic institutions must find creative ways to adapt educational programming for students interested in neurosurgery. Our study serves as a medium for students to dialogue with organized neurosurgery as to what interventions they believe will be most beneficial. The most cited interventions were virtual mentorship pairings and virtual skills workshops. Some efforts are underway to meet these requests at our own institution, which will be offering virtual simulation training and webinars in neurosurgical anatomy. Another Guadix 14 example is the AANS mentorship program, in which student members can match with mentors based on their needs and interests. This program is especially valuable for first and second year students who have yet to find mentors in neurosurgery. In addition, increasing numbers of presentation-based webinars are also being offered by neurosurgical organizations. Finally, as indicated by many in our survey, medical students have been hopeful for a consensus statement from neurosurgical organizations on how some of these specific changes will affect students in their residency application process. The Society of Neurological Surgeons (SNS) recently released a statement cancelling all away neurosurgery rotations. Similar communications from organized neurosurgery on other aspects of the path to residency will deepen trust with students and offer much needed guidance. Above all, the results of our study highlight the uncertainty that medical students interested in neurosurgery are still facing during this time.

Our study has a number of limitations. First, this study is limited by fact that data was collected by self-report survey and therefore is susceptible to response bias. For instance, students may have responded in a manner that overestimates their concern, knowing that this survey might be used to inform neurosurgical education programming. Second, the majority of our cohort showed high levels of interest in neurosurgery, so the results may not accurately capture the experiences and perceptions of medical students who are still in earlier stages of contemplation regarding a career in the field. Third, it is limited by the respondents being either past or future registrants for the Medical Student Neurosurgery Training Camp, and therefore may not be representative of all medical students intending to pursue a career in neurosurgery.

This study, however, successfully captures a large, geographically diverse cohort of US medical students. For example, 34 of our respondents were M3s which, given that the average number of U.S. neurosurgery residency applicants over the previous 5 years is 247 13 , we have captured Guadix 15 approximately 13.8% of next year's applicant cohort. It is important to note that the cohort of students captured by our study were found to include higher proportions of female and ethnic/racial minority students than 2018-2019 U.S. neurosurgery residents found in the ACGME database, This may illustrate a trend in the kinds of medical students who are pursuing a career in neurosurgery. However, it remains unclear if this relation translates into which subsets of students in our study eventually apply to neurosurgery residency. Finally, while we believe that many of our conclusions are applicable to trainees at other stages of their neurosurgical training, including residents, our survey focused only on medical students.
Additional studies may help clarify the challenges faced by other neurosurgical trainees in order to increase generalizability of our findings.

In the midst of the COVID-19 pandemic this nationwide survey highlights the concerns of medical students interested in neurosurgery, how their education and research have been altered as a result of this pandemic, and how their preparatory plans for residency may have changed. In this paper, we also shed light on what strategies medical students perceive to be beneficial for their continued education and mentorship. With these findings in mind, neurosurgery departments and organizations can consider targeted plans, stratified by year in medical school, for students to make up for lost experience due to COVID-19. Table 1 . Respondent demographics stratified by medical student year. No demographic factor varied significantly between medical student years, but our cohort had significantly higher proportions of female and racial/ethnic minorities compared to 2018-2019 neurosurgery residents in the US.

FIGREF0.text: of 2018-2019 U.S. neurosurgery residents, we found that our sample contained a significantly higher proportion of female students (P < .0001 ), racial minorities (P = .03 ), and ethnic minorities (P < .0001 ). Respondents represented 56 different medical institutions, from 27 states across the U.S. (Figure 1). The proportions of students at each medical school who responded to the survey are contained in Supplemental Table 1. The large representation from the west and northeast regions of the U.S. closely mirrors the distribution found in previous studies involving students from the Medical Student Neurosurgery Training Camp 5,8,9 . The mean student interest level in neurosurgery was 88.8 +/-15.2 with 0 being labeled "tangential interest" and 100 labeled "firm commitment."

FIGREF1.text: Shown are the number of respondents from 56 medical institutions within 27 states across the U.S.

FIGREF2.text: would be most affected by the COVID-19 pandemic (Figure 2). Concerns regarding conferences/networking opportunities (63%), clinical experience (59%), board exam scores (42%), sub-internships (39%), and clinical research experience (38%) were most frequently cited. These factors were also stratified by medical trainee year. 79% (31/39) of M1 students were concerned about the impact of COVID-19 on conferences/networking opportunities. 92% (23/25) and 76% (19/25) of M2 students were concerned about board exams and clinical experience, respectively. 91% (31/34) of M3 students reported concerns about sub-internships, while 74% (25/34) were concerned about letters of recommendation and 65% (22/34) about the residency application/interview trail. Concerns over how COVID-19 would impact surgical skills

FIGREF3.text: Aspects of neurosurgical residency application that students expect to be most affected by COVID-19 policies stratified by medical student year. Students in their PhD or research year (N = 16) were excluded for better visualization.

FIGREF4.text: Self-reported likelihood score (0 = Not taking a year off, 100 = Certainly taking a year off) of taking a year off from medical school before and after the start of COVID-19 stratified by medical student year(N = 112) Respondents reported being more likely to take a year off after the start of the COVID-19 pandemic than they were previously for each medical student year. However, this was not statistically significant when analyzed by each individual year. Plotted values represent mean self-reported likelihood score. Error bars represent standard error.

FIGREF5.text: Potential educational programs that students prefer to see neurosurgical organizations offer. Students in PhD or research year (N = 16) were excluded for better visualization. Students were asked to report what educational programs could be offered by neurosurgical organizations (AANS, CNS, etc.) to ensure trainee development during this time (Figure 5). Virtual mentorship programs and virtual surgical skills workshops were each suggested by 67% of students, while 62% of students suggested neurosurgery education webinars, and 46% suggested virtual research symposia. The highest rated educational intervention suggested from M1 and M2 students was virtual mentorship pairing with faculty.

TABREF1.text: Types of clinical experience changes due to COVID-19 policies stratified by medical stud entyear .

TABREF2.text: Means by which medical students are attempting to stay productive during the COVID-19 pandemic.

TABREF3.text: Self-reported score from 0 (Not taking a year off) to 100 (Certainly taking a year off) stratified by medical student year. Students reported being more likely to take a year off after the start of the COVID-19 (P = .004). While this relationship remained consistent for each student year, this was not shown to be statistically significant.

back_matter.text: Funding: This research did not receive any specific grant from funding agencies in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
